db:abstract.db:para: A simple chat between a server and a remote client running in a browser.

db:article.db:para: Standalone demonstrates how to use the QWebChannel C++ API to communicate with an external client. It is a simple chat between a C++ application and a remote HTML client running in your default browser.

db:section.db:title: Running the Example
db:section.db:para: To run the example from Qt Creator, open the Welcome mode and select the example from Examples. For more information, visit Building and Running an Example.

db:section.db:title: Communicating with a Remote Client
db:section.db:para: The C++ application sets up a QWebChannel instance and publishes a Dialog object over it. For the remote client side, index.html is opened. Both show a dialog with the list of received messages and an input box to send messages to the other end.

The Dialog emits the Dialog::sendText() signal when the user sends a message. The signal automatically gets propagated to the HTML client. When the user enters a message on the HTML side, Dialog::receiveText() is called.

All communication between the HTML client and the C++ server is done over a WebSocket. The C++ side instantiates a QWebSocketServer and wraps incoming QWebSocket connections in QWebChannelAbstractTransport objects. These objects are then connected to the QWebChannel instance.
